intro: Haplopappus hartwegii, commonly known as the Hartweg's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bract structures. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its small, yellow to orange flowers are arranged in dense clusters, and the plant produces a unique, hairless pappus that aids in seed dispersal. Haplopappus hartwegii is often found in rocky or sandy habitats, contributing to the ecological diversity of its native range.
